prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, so I need to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. Let me read through the situation again carefully.

The author is in a relationship where they and their girlfriend live together. He pays all the rent and bills because she only works part-time. Then there was this incident where he left his wallet and asked her to pay for the takeout, which was under $40. She had an ugly attitude, acting disgusted and put out. Now he's considering making her start paying some bills because of this one incident. He feels she should carry her weight, even if she can't pay a lot.

So, the question is whether the author is in the wrong. Let's break it down.

First, their financial arrangement: he's paying everything. She works part-time. Maybe they didn't have an agreement before, but he never minded until this incident. The problem here is that he's using one incident as a catalyst to change their financial responsibilities. The key points here are communication, expectations, and fairness.

The author might feel taken advantage of, but he's making a big change (making her pay bills) over a $40 incident. That seems a bit harsh. Maybe he's venting frustration that had been building up. But is it fair to make her pay part of the bills because of one instance where she didn't want to pay a small amount?

Also, the girlfriend's reaction: she might have been upset not just because of the money but because of the sudden shift in expectations. If he's been paying everything for a while, she might not have budgeted for contributing. Her attitude could be from surprise or feeling it's unfair suddenly being asked to pay. But her response was unkind, which is valid for him to be upset about.

However, using a single incident as the reason to demand financial contributions might be a bit extreme. Relationships require communication. The author might have his own issues with the financial arrangement and the incident was the trigger. But is it fair to make her pay because of that one time, especially if she can't afford much?

Also, part-time work might mean her income is limited. If he's paying rent and bills, maybe her part-time job covers her personal expenses. If he wants her to contribute to bills, they need to discuss it. But holding a grudge over a $40 incident to make her start paying might not be fair. It's more about his own feelings of being taken advantage of, and he's using the incident as a reason to change the dynamic.

So, is the author in the wrong? Well, he's angry about the incident and wants to make a change. But the way he's approaching it—using one incident to demand financial contributions without prior discussion—could be seen as unfair. Relationships require mutual agreement and communication. If he's been paying everything and now wants her to contribute, that's a reasonable request, but the manner and the reason (a single incident) might be problematic. Therefore, the author might be in the wrong for making it about that one incident rather than addressing the underlying issue through discussion.
